title: Wingstop will launch a chicken sandwich with 12 flavor varieties in September; The chicken sandwich wars continue and Wingstop is entering the battle
text:
Details about the sandwiches are scarce for now, but during the test process, they were served with the chain's blue cheese and ranch dipping sauces.

"The results of our market tests showcased the opportunity to launch the sandwich nationally achieving our targeted sales mix levels of approximately 4%, while maintaining the simplicity of our operations," said Michael Skipworth, Wingstop's chief executive, on the earnings call, according to FactSet.

See: Outback parent Bloomin' Brands beats on earnings and raises revenue outlook but revises profit guidance below expectations

Skipworth said the sandwich was a good fit for the lunchtime period. He also talked up the company's confidence in its full-year guidance for low-single-digit same-store sales growth, which not only relies on new items, but core chicken wings and value bundles.

"[W]e are experiencing meaningful deflation in our business as the price of wings has normalized from unusually high levels in 2021," he said.

Wingstop WING shares were up 5.6% on Friday following the second-quarter earnings announcement, and have rallied more than 66% over the past month. The benchmark S&P 500 index SPX is up 8.4% for the last month.

Stifel downgraded Wingstop to hold from buy and maintained its $120 price target.

"We have a favorable view of the company's near-term sales outlook and longer-term growth prospects, but with the stock now at our 12-month target price, we believe the near-term risk/reward has become more balanced," analysts wrote.

Benchmark's analysts noted the success the company has already enjoyed from one of its bundles: a boneless wing value deal that included 20 boneless wings, two dips and large french fries priced at $15.99. The deal was introduced just when lower-income customers, who make up a "sizeable" portion of Wingstop's customer base, started to feel the squeeze of inflation, Benchmark notes.

And: Robots are making french fries, chicken wings and more as restaurant kitchens gear up for an automated future

Don't miss: Where can you try McDonald's meatless McPlant burger? Analysts are having trouble tracking the Beyond Meat offering on U.S. menus.

"Wingstop management remains focused on the same growth algorithm that has made the company one of the leading growth restaurant concepts and is currently using a proven playbook to stimulate consumer spending in a choppy economic environment," Benchmark wrote in a note.

"Even with the recent correction in wing prices, management remains intently focused on creating a supply chain solution that will allow the company to remove much of the volatility from bone-in wing pricing going forward."

Benchmark rates Wingstop shares a hold.

"Focus (and investor debate) from here is on executing against the initiatives to drive accelerating traffic and sales amid an increasingly pressured spending environment," wrote UBS in a note.

UBS rates Wingstop stock neutral with a $125 price target, up from $105.

Wingstop will launch a chicken sandwich with 12 flavor varieties in September
